description: Uncertain. Probably a back-formation from Middle English whit ers (“white arse”), after the prominent white rump of many species. Compare dialect forms white rump, white-tail. Possibly a compound of wheat +‎ ear or white +‎ ear. Attested since the seventeenth century as wheat-ears or wheatgear.

definitionGroups.group: Any of various passerine birds of the genus Oenanthe that feed on insects,

description: From Middle English whete-ere, equivalent to wheat +‎ ear.

entries.meaning: A decorative pattern resembling an ear of wheat.
